text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
MessageHeader 0..*MessageHeaderA resource that describes a message that is exchanged between systems
meta
profile 0..*uriProfiles this resource claims to conform to
tag
system 0..1uriIdentity of the terminology system
Required Pattern: http://spms.min-saude.pt/iop/event-meta-tags
event 0..1CodingCode for the event this message represents
system 0..1uriIdentity of the terminology system
Required Pattern: http://spms.min-saude.pt/iop/events
code 0..1codeSymbol in syntax defined by the system
Binding: (unbound) (required)
display 0..1stringRepresentation defined by the system
Required Pattern: MED_PRESCRIPTION_SYNCHRONIZATION
destination
name 0..1string<Aplicação de Origem>
endpoint 1..1uri<Fornecedor da Aplicação/Aplicação de Origem>
receiver 0..1Reference(Organization)Corresponde à organização que recebe a prescrição de medicação.
sender 0..1Reference(Organization)Corresponde à organização que envia a a prescrição de medicação.
timestamp Σ1..1instantTime that the message was sent
author 0..1Reference(Practitioner)Profissional que fez a prescrição de medicação para o utente.
response
details 0..1Reference(OperationOutcome)Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de erro /problemas na recepção/processamento da mensagem.
focus S1..1Reference(RequestGroup)Corresponde ao retorno da receita contendo o identidicador central da receita e o Pin da receita. Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de sucesso na recepção/processamento da mensagem. Só deve ser enviada uma referência para o recurso RequestGroup por mensagem.

Documentation for this format

name: PEMHMessageHeaderResposta
title: Perfil Bundle de mensagem de resposta
description: Este recurso deve ser a primeira entrada no Bundledas mensagens resposta de ACK de transporte e aplicacional, e deve trazer informação sobre o resultado da recepção ou processamento da mensagem pelo cliente destino.

element.short: A resource that describes a message that is exchanged between systems
element.definition: The header for a message exchange that is either requesting or responding to an action.  The reference(s) that are the subject of the action as well as other information related to the action are typically transmitted in a bundle in which the MessageHeader resource instance is the first resource in the bundle.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain any narrative
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the URL. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comment: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.definition: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comment: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.definition: A list of profiles (references to [StructureDefinition](http://hl7.org/fhir/STU3/structuredefinition.html#) resources) that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to [StructureDefinition.url]().
element.comment: It is up to the server and/or other infrastructure of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over time.  The list of profile URLs is a set.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.definition: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comment: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource  The list of security labels is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

binding.description: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

element.definition: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comment: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.  The list of tags is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

binding.description: Codes that represent various types of tags, commonly workflow-related; e.g. "Needs review by Dr. Jones"

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Code for the event this message represents
element.definition: Code that identifies the event this message represents and connects it with its definition. Events defined as part of the FHIR specification have the system value "http://hl7.org/fhir/message-events".
element.requirements: Drives the behavior associated with this message.

binding.description: One of the message events defined as part of FHIR.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.definition: The destination application which the message is intended for.
element.comment: There SHOULD be at least one destination, but in some circumstances, the source system is unaware of any particular destination system.
element.requirements: Indicates where message is to be sent for routing purposes.  Allows verification of "am I the intended recipient".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: Human-readable name for the target system.
element.requirements: May be used for routing of response and/or to support audit.

element.short: Particular delivery destination within the destination
element.definition: Identifies the target end system in situations where the initial message transmission is to an intermediary system.
element.requirements: Supports multi-hop routing.

element.definition: Indicates where the message should be routed to.
element.comment: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
element.requirements: Identifies where to route the message.

element.short: Corresponde à organização que recebe a prescrição de medicação.
element.definition: Allows data conveyed by a message to be addressed to a particular person or department when routing to a specific application isn't sufficient.
element.requirements: Allows routing beyond just the application level.

mapping.map: Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText

element.short: Corresponde à organização que envia a a prescrição de medicação.
element.definition: Identifies the sending system to allow the use of a trust relationship.
element.comment: Use case is for where a (trusted) sending system is responsible for multiple organizations, and therefore cannot differentiate based on source endpoint / authentication alone.
element.requirements: Allows routing beyond just the application level.

mapping.map: Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText

element.short: Time that the message was sent
element.definition: The time that the message was sent.
element.requirements: Allows limited detection of out-of-order and delayed transmission.  Also supports audit.

element.short: The source of the data entry
element.definition: The person or device that performed the data entry leading to this message. When there is more than one candidate, pick the most proximal to the message. Can provide other enterers in extensions.
element.comment: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map: EVN-5 / ORC-10 / PRT-5:PRT-4='EP' / ROL where ROL.3 is EP or ORC.10

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="ENT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])

element.short: Profissional que fez a prescrição de medicação para o utente.
element.definition: The logical author of the message - the person or device that decided the described event should happen. When there is more than one candidate, pick the most proximal to the MessageHeader. Can provide other authors in extensions.
element.comment: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map: ORC-19 / PRT-5:PRT-4='AUT' / ROL where ROL.3 is IP or ORC.12

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="AUT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])

element.definition: The source application from which this message originated.
element.requirements: Allows replies, supports audit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: Human-readable name for the source system.
element.requirements: May be used to support audit.

element.short: Name of software running the system
element.definition: May include configuration or other information useful in debugging.
element.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.

element.definition: Can convey versions of multiple systems in situations where a message passes through multiple hands.
element.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.

element.definition: An e-mail, phone, website or other contact point to use to resolve issues with message communications.
element.requirements: Allows escalation of technical issues.

mapping.map: unique(./entity[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="DEV"]/scopesRole[normalRole() and classCode="CON" and layer[classCode="PSN"]/telecom[isNormalDatatype()])

element.short: Actual message source address or id
element.definition: Identifies the routing target to send acknowledgements to.
element.comment: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
element.requirements: Identifies where to send responses, may influence security permissions.

element.definition: The person or organization that accepts overall responsibility for the contents of the message. The implication is that the message event happened under the policies of the responsible party.
element.comment: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map: ORC-12 /  PRT-5:PRT-4='OP' /  PRT-8:PRT-4='OP' / ROL where ROL.3 is RO or ORC.11

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode="PSN" and determinerCode="INST"] or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/scoper[isNormalEntity() and classCode="ORG" and determinerCode="INST"])

element.definition: Coded indication of the cause for the event - indicates  a reason for the occurrence of the event that is a focus of this message.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track why resources are being changed and report in the audit log/history of the resource.  May affect authorization.

mapping.map: EVN.4 / ORC.16 / OBR-31-reason for study / BPO-13-BP indication for use / RXO-20-indication / RXE-27-give indication / RXD-21-indication / RXG-22-indication / RXA-19-indication

element.short: If this is a reply to prior message
element.definition: Information about the message that this message is a response to.  Only present if this message is a response.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: The MessageHeader.id of the message to which this message is a response.
element.requirements: Allows receiver to know what message is being responded to.

element.definition: Code that identifies the type of response to the message - whether it was successful or not, and whether it should be resent or not.
element.comment: This is a generic response to the request message. Specific data for the response will be found in MessageHeader.focus.
element.requirements: Allows the sender of the acknowledge message to know if the request was successful or if action is needed.

binding.description: The kind of response to a message

element.short: Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de erro /problemas na recepção/processamento da mensagem.
element.definition: Full details of any issues found in the message.
element.comment: This SHALL be contained in the bundle. If any of the issues are errors, the response code SHALL be an error.
element.requirements: Allows the sender of the message to determine what the specific issues are.

element.short:
Corresponde ao retorno da receita contendo o identidicador central da receita e o Pin da receita.
Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de sucesso na recepção/processamento da mensagem.
Só deve ser enviada uma referência para o recurso
RequestGroup por mensagem.
element.definition: The actual data of the message - a reference to the root/focus class of the event.
element.comment: The data is defined where the transaction type is defined. The transaction data is always included in the bundle that is the full message.  Only the root resource is specified.  The resources it references should be contained in the bundle but are not also listed here.  Multiple repetitions are allowed to cater for merges and other situations with multiple focal targets.
element.requirements: Every message event is about actual data, a single resource, that is identified in the definition of the event, and perhaps some or all linked resources.

mapping.map: unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/outboundRelationship[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalActRelatoinship]/target)

element.short: Corresponde à organização que recebe a prescrição de medicação.
Corresponde à organização que envia a a prescrição de medicação.
Time that the message was sent
element.definition: The time that the message was sent.
element.requirements: Allows limited detection of out-of-order and delayed transmission.  Also supports audit.

element.short: Profissional que fez a prescrição de medicação para o utente.
Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de erro /problemas na recepção/processamento da mensagem.

Corresponde ao retorno da receita contendo o identidicador central da receita e o Pin da receita.
Obrigatório enviar apenas em caso de sucesso na recepção/processamento da mensagem.
Só deve ser enviada uma referência para o recurso
RequestGroup por mensagem.
